author: BruceBlitzHasTits

text:
The Network Computer idea flopped, and over my dead body, and with most fervent prayer, until Hell freezes over,  may everything like it continue to flop, for the obvious reason that NO ONE in their right mind would trust any corporation enough to let such store and manage ALL of their personal data, and with it the total record of their identity and activity.  That would be the final kiss of death to liberty, by which one says  goodbye utterly and forever to privacy, security, content sharing, and control over deletions, subscription rates, software, speed and reliability of access, portability, device compatibility, and God only knows what else.  If Ellison had a soul to sell to Satan, there is no devilish pact that is beneath him, or regime or institution too appalling for him to deal with.   If he could get away with it. he'd make over the entire internet into a monopoly, with himself as sole owner and CEO.  He would then proceed to make himself alone immortal, by uploading his brain into the network, from which he would reign absolute, perpetually free to exercise perpetual tyranny, and everlastingly crap the very face of Earth with his self-ware.  He would try to sell the idea to Oprah, and her reaction, again, would be,  "Will it erase me?"   If not exactly in words to that effect, though in tone it would amount to it.  
        I'm sure he still hates the PC.   It's far too personal en extension of the average user's will for his taste.﻿

author: tanio12

text:
+tanio12
Taking that story face value consider this.
1. There is no way that Manchester made it known that that MBA would attract that salary.

2. If reading a bunch of books with no real world experience can be that valuable to an organisation, why would they not just buy the  books (for a lot less than 1.8 million dollars) and pay a whole team of their apprentice option traders to read them.

Then pay the best one (based on actual options performance) $200K saving a lot of money.

I will tell you why. No ,employer pays over the odds for graduates of any programme unless there is a connection that is not accessible to the ordinary student.

So if you are an ordinary member of that school and took on the five figure debt to get that degree, that is NOT the salary you are going to be offered.

This is known as the lottery fallacy. One guy hit the jackpot so everyone should spend all their earnings on lottery tickets.

3. I graduated from Oxford so I have some insight into how this works. There are secret seminars and courses, for the chosen few.

But they are chosen by family ties. Like people who get to join secret societies like skull and bones at Yale.

They are not awarded on Merit. So an ordinary student would be ill-advised getting into debt to get onto such an exclusive programme.﻿

author: Str1000ac

text:
+Str1000ac

Larry Ellison one in a million
Steven Jobs, two in a million
Bill Gates three in a million
Paul Allen (Gate's partner) four in a million
Richard Branson five in a million
Alan Sugar (The Apprentice guy) six in a million
Michael Dell seven in a million

I could keep going and going Warren Avis (Rent-a-car)

Yes there are smart people cleaning streets, many of them paying off student debt they ran up in the  process.

And no, I do not equate success with money, but I also don't equate education with sitting in a classroom being told what and how to think at a massive cost.

Getting churned out of school with the same knowledge and attitudes as all ones class mates is not conducive to original thinking.

The world is changing extremely fast. Old mantras like a job for life and a career no longer apply.

If you go and work for a big corporation today you will be drawing welfare  in 10 years. All the corporations that want to survive are slashing costs by automation.

The process is just getting started. Drones, automated checkouts, driverless planes, automatic pilots, computerised factories...

People who follow the programme will be surplus to requirements really soon.

If you want to enter the lottery to be one of the lucky few, the job market equivalent of the hunger games, good luck.﻿

author: Str1000ac

text:
+Str1000ac
Student debt is not limited to the US.
http://www.usnews.com/education/best-global-universities/articles/2013/11/13/undergrads-around-the-world-face-student-loan-debt

But it is true that levels are lower in other parts of the world. But my focus is no US and UK.

Your first post where you stated that the people who I cited are not perfect human beings is irrelevant to the topic at hand.

If I listed a lot of college graduates who lied and cheated their way to the top, how would that inform you as to the value of education?

The fact is that what happens in schools and universities has little to do with education.

The fundamental deliverable of an education is the produce self directed individuals who can learn new information and ideas independently.

This is not what most graduates achieve. They spend most of their lives looking for others to direct their time and energy and spend much of their income on the output of others.

During the industrial age this was a viable way to live. Today it isn't since the idea of a job for life is gone.

The implied contract which allowed students to passively absorb some else's curriculum but then be given a living by an institution that had no say in that curriculum is gone.

China and India turn out engineers at a fraction of the cost the west does, and they will work for 40% or less of the pay.

Furthermore with rapidly expanding automation, nobody knows which jobs will still be needed in ten years.

One thing higher education does not teach is flexibility or self sufficiency.

People who can't find jobs are increasingly helpless. And jobs and the income from jobs is vanishing fast in what was the industrialised world.﻿

author: Str1000ac

text:
+Str1000ac

1. The main value of college is networking. This fact is openly flaunted before you.

" George Bush C student, John Carey, C student. But they were both Skull and Bones members and ran for president."

Try getting in the middle of that argument with a 4.0 grade point average!

JFK and Roosvelt were also C students but very capable presidents.

A clear indication that absorbing college education is not what leads to success after college.

2. College is not synonymous with education. Education implies an interactive process by which one learns to observe, adapt to and manipulate ones environment.

College is the absorption of a curriculum abstracted from an ever changing world.


3. College graduates are more employable than non graduates is a theory which few employers bother to test.

Many so called "uneducated people"  in getto schools for example, are in fact people who have been seriously damaged by the education system.

Often when the consequences of dropping out are examined, these illiterate and often criminalised people are held up as an example.

Being forced to go to school (which by law we all are) and thus prevented from taking up any alternative means of education (like apprenticeship of starting a business) does not lead to a valid comparison.

4. Many great companies have been founded by people who did things that are now considered to be illegal.

Edison started his first business at 13. School attendance laws would now forbid this.

The reason why school and college don't look worse than they do is that they have effectively outlawed most competing activities until people are too old to fully exploit the opportunities they bring.

The school reading charts consider child to read like an adult at 13 but forbid employment for 3 more years.

Most jobs require little more than literacy and numeracy for training to begin. So think why this delay is built in?

Children can go to jail earlier than they can go to work. (Juvenile detention is jail, don't let the name fool you)﻿

But BELIEVING that being well-educated would automatically makes one's successful in his/her pursuit is 100% wrong.﻿

author: gadget00

text:
I don't think they're completely crap, Only real Oracle professionals should use Oracle because there is a steep learning curve.  A monkey with only a little training can turn MySQL on and get it going and it will most likely perform almost as good as it ever will go  (minus data corruption which the DBA will still need to spend a lot of time learning how to prevent.)

Oracle punishes incompetence by needing more hardware when you do dumb things.    (being dumb costs a lot on Oracle)  MySQL is very forgiving.

Though I will happily use PostgreSQL before inflicting the pain of having to use MySQL.  I might pick flat files if I only had a choice between MySQL and flat files.

It has the most advance partitioning and sub partitioning implementation by far.  Way more options for customizing business solutions.   Makes PaaS work a breeze. 

The most advance optimizer that can handle every sophisticated way to model data (except graph data.)   This includes trivial things like nested sub queries which MySQL still hasn't figured out last time I checked to more advance things like recursive queries which should not even be attempted in MySQL.

You do not have to "pause" the database when doing backups in Oracle.    There are lots of MySQL pros that know all the secrets to minimize database corruption and I appreciate that.  There is still something that makes me question MySQL as being mature if you have to spend most of your DBA time learning how to prevent data corruption.  I would rather focus on learning how to optimize my business app.﻿

author: Lester Barrett

text: +ExtendedGamer I see that you withdrew your comment.  It didn't really make sense to me.  By your logic, everyone who owns a grocery store is a humanitarian because they feed so many people.  Con Agra would be a great benefactor because they feed many millions.  Also, I totally reject your allegation that he Ellison did more than MLK, JFK, and Mandela.  He isn't even on the same order of magnitude.  Even if he had steadfastly given everything he made to charity, he would not have done as much for humanity as those three.  Your comment reflected a very narrow understanding of history.﻿
author: Lester Barrett

text:
+ExtendedGamer I can understand your view of his generosity.  We must disagree on the impact of the other three.  I believe that each of them had an impact that was much larger than you say.  MLK's message and actions resonate throughout the world and will continue to do so for many generations.  Mandela shepherded a peaceful process of reconciliation.  It was not perfect; but it prevented a large amount of bloodshed.  Improving the lives of a lower class in every country is an ongoing process.  He will forever remain a part of that.  JFK gave hope and new vision to the world, although one could argue that he did not actually accomplish anything as a President.  He inspired even in countries that were our enemies.  

I would say that Bill Gates is more known for charitable endeavors than Ellison.  He is trying to eradicate polio and many other problems.  Jimmy Carter has also been busy working to eradicate a number of third world problems.  

I believe that no matter how much money and toys I have, as long as I live in a world where poverty is excessive, I am not wealthy.﻿

author: DwightUIgnorantSlut1

text:
Not everyone needs to have a major impact on humanity.  I firmly believe that those who extract a large amount of resources of any type owe more back to humanity.  It is obscene to spend the money on toys when you consider the conditions of life for America's poor.  Third world poor people are an order of magnitude below even our poor.

Look at the examples of Bill Gates, Robert Wood Johnson, and Dr. Jonas Salk, for example.  Read about Dr. Salk.  He could have been a lot richer than the CEO of Oracle.  I would argue that, in spite of what people said in other comments here, that Salk did more for humanity than Gates, Ellison, and many other rich people combined.  Due to inappropriate use of vaccination teams for spying by the CIA, Polio has sprung up again in Pakistan, where the Taliban have killed nearly a hundred aid workers who were conducting vaccination campaigns.  This year there have been about one hundred cases there.  If this epidemic spreads, it could affect someone you know.  When I was a child, it was not uncommon to see polio victims everywhere in the United States, and even more common overseas.  It was sad to see young children on crutches with metal exoskeletons on their legs, or in wheelchairs.  This disease affected hundreds of millions; and it was and is totally eradicable.  Maybe Ellison could take up where Salk left off, if he is not too busy sailing.

 http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jonas_Salk﻿
author: Lester Barrett

text: I think he's a success story, to be honest. There isn't much to be done in business without big ideas. The environment is always a concern, and so is privacy; on the other hand, look at all that Oracle has done... It's incredible. Without advances in technology for civil, medical, and information, we may not be able to keep with the pace of humanity's growth.﻿

author: Sam Boris

text:
+Samuel Atem So are you an Oracle employee trying to look good, or just hoping for a job?  Do you understand that Ellison is a public figure?  That means millions of people are going to have opinions about him, some positive, and some negative.  People are going to express those opinions, and rightly so.  If you go to a restaurant and express the opinion that your meal is substandard, does your date ask what have you cooked lately that tastes better?  If you express your disgust at the way GM has been covering up defective ignition switches for years, do your friends ask you what you have personally done about auto safety?  Does it make you better than GM to complain about their safety policies?  If you criticize Wall Street bankers, does your mother ask you what makes you better than them?   

Tell me this:  Do you feel that whenever someone anywhere criticizes anyone, they are implying that they are better than that person?  Also, when someone makes a comment on the internet, do you feel that they need to defend their comment to every nitwit that comes along, such as yourself?

And for your information, I do believe that on a proportional scale, I am more generous with my money than your would-be boss.﻿
